Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2009 06:46AM slmdavidson wrote: Hi Debisongbird I just quickly read your last post and will offer up my experience.  They do cover my legs with a blanket when I lay down and then once they have all the lines lined up, they cover me up with my half-gown shirt thingy I wear.  There is no reason you have to be completely exposed during the rad treatment.  It will go right through your gown.  You should ask about it.  I think I've been lucky that I have a great Rad Onc and great techs.  Good luck Laura
Posts.Title: February 2009 rads group - all aboard!! Lories sobx

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2009 08:32AM slmdavidson wrote: Unique - your little circles sound like what they described to me.  Small circular tape to cover the marks so it doesn't get washed off.  I was told that if I wanted, I could eventually go with very small permanent tattoos instead.  Actually, my simulation is tomorrow, so I'm sure by then I'll be completely schooled in all of this.  Jane - Looks like you and I are on the same schedule!  You also sound like me on the research.  I have a medical background anyway, but my husband gives me a hard time for spending so much time on the internet.  But knowledge is power and I read, read, read!  I'm sorry to hear about your Rad Onc's poor bedside manner.  There could have been a better way to say that.  I will need to ask about the deodorant and creams.  Can you get those deodorants anywhere?  Great hearing from all of you ladies.

Between daily trips to the Cancer Center, working 4 days a week, trying to recruit people for the Race for the Cure, family etc..... I've just hardly been on here. I have TWO treatments left to go.  April Fools Day I'll be ringing that bell, but it won't be a joke!  Can't believe it's finally here.  In some respects the time has flown by.  Will be glad when my chest isn't red and irritated but otherwise, this hasn't been too bad.  I've been a little more tired this past week or so, so it must be catching up to me.  Hope you are all doing well and will soon be off this train!  It's time for cancer to stop running my life.  Hugs to you all, Laura

The skin should be able to move, but is not.  I will ask at my next appt in two weeks, but wondering if massage would be able to break it up? Laura

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2009 04:42PM slmdavidson wrote: Oh I see.  Hmmm, you would think they could fill in that area with some kind of fat or filler if it's a small area.  I heard recently they've started doing fat injections to help fill out the breast when doing mastectomies/reconstructions.  I'd think about seeing another PS and get a second opinion.  I suggest sending out a post looking for a great PS near Milwaukee.  You might get some good doctors suggested by the ladies on the board.  They are a great resource! Good luck, Laura
Posts.Title: Bad lumpectomy followed by bad plastic surgery choco-inc slmdavidson

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2009 09:19PM slmdavidson wrote: Hi tblaise.  During the mastectomy/reconstruction, they'll place an "expander" under the chest skin/muscle where your breast was.  Think of this as basically a refillable implant.  THey'll put some saline in it to start, and continue to add water through a port each few weeks until you get to the size you are wanting.  Those stay in for a few months and it allows your skin and muscles to stretch slowly over this period of time.  Then during another surgery, they will take those out and put in permant implants.  It took me a while to get the grasp of what the expander was or what it was used for, so I hope that helps.   Hang in there and read lots, I've learned a lot of stuff on these boards.  Good luck and take care. Laura
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy, Mastectomy or Bi-Lateral Mastectomy movinOn movinOn

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2009 08:24PM slmdavidson wrote: Hi Movingon.  Glad to hear you've made peace with a decision.  I had multi-focal DCIS at the time of my first diagnosis in Sep 07.  I was given no choice other than mastectomy since it was in every quadrant in my R breast.  I choose to do the bilateral mx with latisimus flap reconstruction at that time.  I am on the thinner side and didn't have enough belly and skin for the tummy tuck procedure. In Feb 08 had the expanders switched out for implants and had the nipple reconstruction done.  I have to say they look amazing.  I had a nurse and a doctor (both who KNEW I had bilat mx) ask me individually if those were my natural nipples.  The scars only 15 months later are barely visible.  I don't regret taking the other side.  They look the same and they look remarkably good.  I golfed better this year without the use of my lats than ever before so I don't regret my decision at all.  Just know, I had a recurrence last month.  It's not a cure all so just make sure you still do breast self exams.  Luckily I found the lump and it looks like I found it early.  Still waiting on the final path report from surgery this past week, but I'm sure it would have been worse, had I not noticed it.  Good luck to you!!!!
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy, Mastectomy or Bi-Lateral Mastectomy movinOn movinOn

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2009 12:26PM slmdavidson wrote: Hi Otter, Thanks so much for the information.  I did just talk with my doctors office and there is a second block that they are sending.  Keeping my fingers crossed that it contains enough material to run the test.  I'm surprised your Oncotype score was so high considering your other stats. My grade was I, but only by a smidge.  I think one more notch on one of those characteristics and it would have been 2 (my DCIS was grade 2).  Our pathologies are fairly similar other than the PR status and of course size. Thanks for sharing the info about my what the plan would be prior to the Oncotype data.  That is good to know and I didn't really know what the standard of care was prior to having this additional info.  I'm signed up with a super Onc, Dr. George Sledge, really a leader in breast cancer so I'm lucky he is here in Indy.  I meet with him on Feb 20.  Regarding your question on recurrence vs residual tumor..... don't really know.  I think my surgeon was sweating bullets initally since he hasn't seen this too much.  From this past lumpectomy, he ended up taking the skin and everything down to the muscle under the biopsy area, plus he scraped underneath the skin beyond that area and sent it all for pathology.  They did an incredibly thorough job of inking with four different colors and sliced the sample 3 times over what they usually do.  They found NO native breast cells in that sample.  Doc was relieved to know he did a "good mastectomy" and I think to me, that still leaves the question open as to if it recurred or was left behind. You would think it could be residual if found with breast cells.  A good question for my Oncologist.  Regarding the nodes, 1 was removed in 2007 and 5 more removed last month.  All were clear so that was a big relief.  I think my "issue" is, I no longer trust the odds.  During the initial investigation, follow up, biopsy, I kept hearing "9 times out of 10 this is nothing".  I kept being that dang 1 of 10. Then with this recurrence, I hear it happens 1% of the time.  So now I'm the 1 out of 100.  I don't want to be the "1" anymore.   I'm sure all of us relate to that.  Even having a low Oncotype score and having a 5-10% recurrence rate, I think I'll be thinking about this the rest of my life!  At least I'll be vigilant about paying attention and thank god I was paying attention when I found that tiny lump!  Thanks for listening and your advice.  p.s.  Yes, I still feel fortunate this is an early non-aggressive cancer.  I'm still one of the lucky ones here. Laura
Posts.Title: Not enough tissue for OncotypeDX? slmdavidson slmdavidson

Posts.Content: slmdavidson wrote: I just got a call from my doctors office. Genomics lab called and said that the sample they received was not large enough to run the Oncotype DX testing.....I've been waiting for this information since Jan 13 from my surgery.  Problem is that they took a chunk out with the biopsy on Dec 18 and then additional sample was taken with the lumpectomy surgery on Jan 13.  It was a small tumor and area (which I realize is a good thing) but I guess they can't put those two pieces together to get enough?  Has anyone else had this?  What did you do?  We were kind of going on the results here to help us with the chemo decision.....  considering my cancer was back 15 months after mastectomy, I'm wondering how aggressive those genes are.  And now I won't know?  There is other data that plays into the score other than the size, grade, ER status, etc. that is already on the path report.   What to do???  ARGGHH!!!!  God, nothing seems to be easy with this cancer. Laura Log in to post a reply
